unit_title: Unit 1 Lecture: Overview of the SAT Reading & Writing Test
audience: High school students preparing for the SAT (Reading & Writing)

teacher_notes.pacing: 45 minutes; overview with modeling and a short practice.
teacher_notes.materials: Slides with module layout, timer, sample item handout.
teacher_notes.assessment: Exit ticket plus 4-item unit check; quick thumbs checks.

learning_objectives: Describe the digital SAT R&W module structure and navigation.
Explain the read–predict–select routine for single-item passages.
Identify common item formats and eliminate off-topic choices.

structure.title: Overview of the Test
objectives: Recognize adaptive modules and single-question passages.

lecture_script.script: The digital SAT R&W uses two adaptive modules with brief passages and one question each. You can flag items and return within a module; all questions are A–D multiple-choice.
I skim for gist, predict in a few words, and then match that prediction to the best option while crossing out choices that are irrelevant or extreme.
We’ll do one sample together: underline the key claim, say your prediction, then choose the option that directly fits it.
Write one sentence describing how you’ll use predict-before-choices on test day.

worked_example.passage: Maya arranged the lab samples methodically, noting that careful order reduced mistakes and sped analysis. Her mentor watched, smiling at the quiet efficiency.
worked_example.question: Which choice best states the main idea of the passage?

options.C: Maya’s organized approach improves accuracy and speed.
options.D: The lab is too noisy for careful work.

worked_example.explanation: Order reduces mistakes and speeds analysis, so organization improves accuracy and speed.

homework: Write a one-paragraph summary of the SAT R&W format.
Complete five items using predict-before-choices and note your evidence phrase.
List three trap patterns you will eliminate quickly.
